title: Color & Conversation
description:
Join us at the Women's Center for our paint & sip event!
A laid-back painting space with simple prompts for inspiration
A colorful mocktail bar and light snacks
Music, conversation, and community in a welcoming atmosphere
This event is free and open to all
Supplies included!

title: Air Clay Creations
description:
Join us for Air Clay Creations at the Graduate Life Center on Wednesday, November 5, 2025! This hands-on workshop is a chance to relax, get creative, and craft your own unique clay pieces using lightweight, air-dry clay. No prior experience is needed‚Äîjust bring your imagination.
Whether you want to sculpt small d√©cor, design personalized gifts, or simply enjoy a mindful break from your routine, this event is the perfect way to express yourself in a fun, low-pressure environment. All materials will be provided.

title: Zine Workshop: Queer Collage
description:
Zine Workshop: Queer Collage
Thursday, November 6 1-3pm in the Pride Center
Come & Collage!
The history of queer collage is marked by its use as a subversive tool to deconstruct and reconstruct identity, creating new worlds and challenging heteronormative assumptions. Artists have used collage to express fluid gender, reclaim historical narratives, and create safe spaces, ranging from the early work of artists like Ray Johnson and political commentary from figures like Ralph Arnold to the contemporary practices of artists like Lovie Olivia and Rakeem Cunningham.
Good vibes, supplies, & snacks provided
For questions or accommodations, contact Haleigh Wallace at
haleighwallace@vt.edu
.
Online submissions also welcome! Submit your piece here:
https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSe02gqux9AiLpzPwZm_QdmPZSP7acWh9AOR8O1NDifJu8_N_Q/viewform?pli=1&authuser=0
This event is open to all and all are welcome to contribute to the project.
For accommodations contact Haleigh Wallace at haleighwallace@vt.edu.

title: Engineering Pathways: From Virginia Tech to Raytheon and Lessons Learned Along the Way
location: Graduate Life Center - Meeting Room F (Room 59)
hosted_by: American Indian Science and Engineering Society at Virginia Tech
description:
Join us for an open dialogue with Dr. Andr√© Dominic Cropper (EE Ph.D ‚Äô95), a distinguished Engineering Fellow at Raytheon as he reflects on his experience at Virginia Tech and beyond.
Dr. Andr√© Dominic Cropper (EE Ph.D ‚Äò95) is a distinguished Engineering Fellow at Raytheon with advanced expertise in hyperspectral imaging, aerospace, and systems engineering. His innovative contributions have significantly enhanced the field of materials science and electrical engineering, earning him multiple patents including early work on technology supporting OLED-based touch screens. His work has been recognized through numerous inventor and STEM awards; including the AISES Professional of the Year award in 2014 and the Caribbean Global Hall of Excellence Lifetime Achievement award in 2025.

title: FUN FRIDAY
hosted_by: Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers
description:
Take a break from classes and join IEEE for a relaxing morning with free Carol Lee donuts!
Whether you're in ECE, CS, or just love good vibes and good treats, swing by to grab a donut and hang out with fellow students and faculty.

title: Learning Lunch with Dr. Chitvan Trivedi
description: Registration Link: http://bit.ly/3HFpz8o

title: LAIGSA Community Lunches
hosted_by: Latin American and Iberian Graduate Students Association
description: During these lunches, Latinx graduate students and friends have the opportunity to connect and engage with one another by sharing and celebrating their cultures. These gatherings not only foster social connections but also provide a chance to exchange stories, traditions, and experiences, enriching the community as a whole. Everyone is welcome!

title: This is How We Roll: Bento Edition
description:
This is How We Roll
Date: Friday, November 7, 2025
Time: 2:00 ‚Äì 4:00 PM ET
Location: Squires Student Center, Room 140
SPECIAL This is How We Roll!
Food often serves as the basis for finding common ground. This is How We Roll is a series that focuses on bringing people together through the theme of food. Each event will feature a different dish that is typically rolled up. Faculty and invited speakers will teach participants recipes and share the historical significance of a particular dish. In November, we will feature bento boxes, a Japanese way of packing lunches Participants will be able to make their own sushi rolls and learn about the origins of this delicious meal. Vegan and vegetarian options available. Registration is required due to space limitations. Light refreshments will be provided.
Space is limited to 40 people. RSVP here to secure your space and choose a timeslot:
https://forms.office.com/r/XcNXfYdgdE
‚Ä¢ Slot A: 2:00 - 3:00pm (20 people max)
‚Ä¢ Slot B: 3:00 - 4:00pm (20 people max)

title: CNRE Graduate Student Pizza Social (November)
location: Cheatham Student Lounge on the 1st floorF
hosted_by: Forestry Graduate Student Association at Virginia Tech
description:
The Forest Resources and Environmental Conservation's Graduate Student Association (FGSA) is hosting another inter-departmental Pizza Night open to all graduate students in the College of Natural Resources and Environment (CNRE)‚Äîincluding Forest Resources and Environmental Conservation, Fish and Wildlife Conservation, Geography, and Sustainable Biomaterials.
By sharing a meal, we aim to break down barriers to participation while fostering collaboration, interdisciplinary dialogue, and resource sharing among CNRE graduate students. These recurring gatherings will provide a consistent, inclusive space that promotes well-being, builds both professional and personal connections, and strengthens our graduate student community.

description: Wesley is hosting a Nintendo Night!! We will have a variety of Nintendo games able to be played around our building.

title: First-Gen BreakZone Takeover
description:
Our annual National First-Generation College Celebration Week Kick-off event, where first-generation students at Virginia Tech TAKE UP SPACE! The entire Break Zone facility is rented out for first-generation students and friends. We will have free games, swag, and food
!

title: Keeping It Real College Life Group
description: Come talk about life with us! This is Church on Main's life group for college students, where all are welcome and loved. We do our best to keep it real, look for grace, and follow God. We meet after the 11:00 service at Church on Main. Currently reading When Christians Get it Wrong by Adam Hamilton.

title: Let's Lock In
description:
DATE: Mondays starting September 15, 2025
TIME: 4:00 ‚Äì 6:00 PM EST
LOCATION: APIDA + Center (140 Squires)
Looking for a weekly boost to stay on track with your classes? Let's Lock In meets once a week ‚Äì every Monday - to give you a dedicated time and space to focus, get support, and make real progress. Join other students in a relaxed, productive environment where tutors are on hand to help with coursework, and other campus resources are just a step away. Think of it like study hall, but better: whether you're tackling tough assignments, prepping for exams, or just trying to stay organized, Let's Lock In is here to help. Drop in, get focused, and leave feeling accomplished.
Co-sponsored with the APIDA + Center/AANAPISI Initiative and the Student Success Center

title: College of Science Scavenger Hunt: First Generation Celebration Week
description:
Join the College of Science for First Generation Celebration Week for a scavenger hunt in Squires! Learn more about resources, connect with other students, and win prizes. Dinner will be provided!
If you are an individual with a disability and desire an accommodation, please contact Jess Hoopengardner at jessh@vt.edu at least 10 business days prior to the event.

description: Wesley is hosting a PJ's & Popcorn Movie Night!! We will be watching Meet the Robinson's!! Come dressed in your best and most comfortable PJ's, there is a prize for the best pajamas!!

description:

Eugene Maurakis

.

title: Hokie Culture Crawl Launch
description:
How it Works
Step 1:
Pick up a passport
Find the passport at the Opening Reception on Tuesday, Nov. 11, between 5 p.m. and 6:00 p.m. in the Perspectives Gallery (Squires Student Center).
If you can't make it to the opening reception, a downloadable passport card will be made available¬† after the opening reception.
Step 2:
Attend as many IEW events as you can!
You will get a unique stamp in your passport for each IEW event you attend. (Online events will send you a digital stamp.)
If you get
at least six stamps
, you've earned your Hokie Culture Cawl 2025 T-shirt designed by the VT Doodler!
Step 3:
Pick up your shirt
At the end of the week, the first 400 students who present passports with at least six stamps at the Multilingual Open Mic Night¬† on Tues., Nov 18 from 6-7:30 (Harper Hall) will get the exclusive t-shirt!
Can't make it to the Multilingual Open Mic Night? Students may also pick up their shirts on Wednesday, Nov. 19 at the Global Education Office during normal business hours.

title: Global Education Office Photo/Video Contest Winner Announcement
description:
Join the Global Education Office (GEO) at the International Education Week (IEW) Opening Reception, where we will unveil the 2024-2025 Photo/Video Contest winners.
Pick up some hors devours catered by Heathwood Marketplace, and enjoy the art of
Eugene Maurakis
at Perspectives Gallery.¬† Winners will be announced at 5:45 pm.

title: Securitas Turner Tuesday - Weekly Community Dinner
description: Every Tuesday this fall, the first five students to meet at Turner Place Dining Hall at 5:15 PM will get their meal covered! Join the Program Director and your fellow Securitas community members for a weekly dinner hangout before your evening class. It‚Äôs a great way to relax, connect, and enjoy good food together. Turner Tuesday runs from August 26 to December 2, 5:15‚Äì6:15 PM. First come, first served!

Queer media club is a monthly space where we gather to talk about all things media: movies, music, books, games, and more! The theme for November is TBD.

All are welcome to join!

description: Join us to make lentil stew and learn about the health and nutritional impacts of lentils!

title: VTable Talk: Senior Panel Discussion
description:
Calling all freshman, sophomores, and juniors!
Join us in the BCC on the 11th of November
for a senior panel discussion on how
to
navigating through the last year attending Virginia Tech. A panel of seniors will be giving pointers out to students on what they can expect, what they should prepare for, and what they need to do to get here in the first place. Food will be
provided
and students can even get one on one time with the panelists before and after the event. All are welcome!

title: Untold Valor Screening
description:
Join us this
Veterans Day
,
November 11th
, for a special screening of
Untold Valor
at the
Lyric Theater
. Doors open at
7:00 PM
! Free and Open to the Public! Registration is Required:
RVSP Link:
https://virginiatech.questionpro.com/a/TakeSurvey?tt=/8ve1MW%2BI3gECHrPeIW9eQ%3D%3D
Untold Valor
follows the incredible story of Corporal Jack Aikins, a young soldier personally recruited by General George S. Patton to join an elite 13-man Comanche task force formed by the U.S. Army during World War II. This covert unit played a pivotal role in the intelligence war, using the Comanche language¬†for battlefield communication. Operating in secrecy across Europe, their bravery and skill safeguarded Allied plans and shaped key victories‚Äîmarking one of the most remarkable chapters of Indigenous service and heroism in American military history.
Following the screening, there will be a
Q&A session
featuring
Choctaw Film Director Ise White
,
Wichita/Comanche Actor Derek Garza
,
Cinematographer John Engstrom
, and
Joe¬†Taylor Chibitty
, a descendant of Comanche Code Talker
Charles J. Chibitty
.
A reception with light refreshments will follow the discussion.
This event is hosted by the School of Visual Arts (SOVA) and¬†Ati Wa: Oki Indigenous Community Center (ICC) and supported by the partnerships of Office of Veteran Services, the¬†Pamplin College of Business, the College of Liberal Arts and Human Sciences, School of Communications, Native@VT, Indigenous Community Garden (ICG), Indigenous Studies Program, Department of Modern and Classical Languages and Literatures, Department of History, Department of Political Science, Academic Success Initiatives, Center for Peace Studies and Violence Prevention
Trailer Link:¬†https://youtu.be/24ymnrZLvLc?si=8blw066K__Q9af3N

title: Mechanical Engineering Graduate Students' Coffee & Donuts Social
description: Get some donuts for them for extra calories and freshly brewed coffee for the extended working hours (courtesy of your PI). Blow off some steam and look forward to some fun chit-chat and lively banter with all the graduate students in the Department of Mechanical Engineering. It is a great platform to discuss work or classes with your ME peers, if you may (we are looking at all you nerds and geeks). Network, socialize, and put on some weight while at it!

title: Giving Thanks Around the World
description:
Kick-off International Education Week with the Graduate School at our annual Giving Thanks Around the World event. Join us for food, drinks, and community with a traditional Thanksgiving meal. Student, faculty, and staff will gather together to celebrate diverse cultures, featuring a shared lunch. Participants are encouraged to bring a small dish, to discuss and share the cultural significance. The Graduate School will provide the main traditional American dishes.
Please RSVP no later than Tuesday, November 5th
so we can have a headcount!
When: Wednesday, November 12th 2025 | 12PM-1:30PM
Where: Boeing Auditorium, Academic Building One
If you have any questions, please reach out to the Graduate School via email at
dcgradschool@vt.edu

title: Multi-Heritage Support Group
description:
The Multi-Heritage Support Group is a monthly wellness program that is an affirming space offering students a chance to share stories, explore the complexity of navigating multiple identities, and build community with others who hold rich and layered identities.
Each session features peer support, open discussions, and guided reflections, facilitated by Dr. Julie Chandler from the Cook Counseling Center and a Peer Wellness Mentor from the AANAPISI Initiative. Topics may include belonging, family dynamics, code-switching, colorism, and navigating societal expectations, and other topics related to multi-heritage identities.
This program is open to all and light refreshments will be provided.
--
If you are an individual with a disability and desire an accommodation, please contact Gia Ha at giaha@vt.edu or 540-231-3399 during regular business hours at least 10 business days prior to the event.
Co-sponsored by AANAPISI Initiative at Virginia Tech, APIDA + Center, Ati: Wa:oki Indigenous Community Center, Cook Counseling Center. Funded by the US Department of Education AANAPISI grant.

title: May the Best Marble Win!
description: Join SL Ricardo and the LSCRC in a night of betting on Marbles to complete a marble race and learn about safe betting strategies! Earn House Cup Points and get pizza by betting on the best marble!

title: First-Gen Student and Faculty Mixer
description:
Join us for our 6th annual Faculty and Student Mixer!
This year, we‚Äôre excited to partner with the School of Engineering‚Äôs Pathways Program and the Scholar Support Office to bring you an evening of connection and community. This event is a mutual opportunity to network, share experiences, and build meaningful relationships. It serves as an important platform to inspire and empower one another as we navigate our educational and professional journeys. Students will also have the opportunity to match with a mentor during the event.
Food will be served. Business casual/professional attire is encouraged.

title: Karaoke Night
description: Warm up those vocal cords for a fun night of karaoke on November 12 from 7pm-9pm! You can pick your own songs to sing your heart out! We'll also be playing karaoke-based games like Blind Karaoke, Guess the Song, and Don't Forget the Lyrics. Bring your friends to Commonwealth Ballroom in Squires for a night of singing-filled fun!

title: The Queer and Trans International Student Experience
description: This event aims to raise awareness of and increase understanding for the experiences of queer and trans international students. Free lunch will be provided by Roots Natural Kitchen. All are welcome to join.

title: November General Body Meeting
description: Join the Roanoke Graduate Student Association for our monthly meeting to¬†discuss initiatives to improve graduate life and wellbeing on the Roanoke FBRI campus. Connect with fellow graduate and professional students over a light lunch of Panera pastries, and learn about RGSA's upcoming events. Come with any questions or comments you may have about life as a graduate student in Roanoke!

title: Graduate Pathways: Building Skills for a Successful Career
description: The goal is to offer a roadmap for academic career progression‚Äîhighlighting how individuals have navigated their paths, the key steps they took, and the strategies that helped them advance. The seminar will provide insight into the practical aspects of building a successful academic career, such as mentorship, networking, balancing responsibilities, and long-term planning.

title: Duck Pond Clean-up with SL Kathleen
description: Come with SL Kathleen to the Duck Pond clean-up hosted by the District 3 team. We'll meet under the arch together and walk over to New Residence Hall East to meet up with the rest of the group and get hot drinks and supplies. Then, we'll start our cleanup and walk to the Duck pond, and return by 6:30. Plus, you get a free rubber duck!

ree ramen samples and ramen-inspired swag (while supplies last). Please RSVP in advance.

title: Thinkful Thursday Game Night: National First-Generation College Celebration Week
description:
Join the GenerationOne Living-Learning Community as we celebrate National First-Generation College Celebration Week with a fun-filled Game Night! Enjoy an evening of board games, VR experiences, card games, arts and crafts, delicious food, and great company. This event is open to everyone, and we especially encourage on-campus first-generation students to join in the celebration. Come connect, unwind, and share in the good vibes with GenerationOne students as we honor NFGCCW together‚Äî
don‚Äôt forget to RSVP!

title: International Film Screening: Ramen Shop @ The Lyric
description:
Join us for a free screening of Ramen Shop at the Lyric Theater!¬† The first 100 people will receive complimentary popcorn!
Movie synopsis:¬† When a young ramen chef from Japan finds his late Singaporean mother's journal, he takes it with him to her native country, hoping to put together the story of his family and his life.
Open to the public

title: First-Gen Graduate Luncheon
description:
Join First-Generation Student Success and the Graduate Life Center for the First-Generation Graduate Luncheon‚Äîa welcoming space for graduate students to connect, learn, and plan for life during and after graduate school. This event offers a unique opportunity for first-generation graduate students to network with peers, faculty, and campus partners while exploring tools and resources that support academic and personal success. All graduate students are welcome to attend and learn more about the support available at Virginia Tech.
Enjoy free lunch, great conversation, and exclusive swag as you build connections and strengthen your graduate experience!

info_urls.label: Talk-O Tuesday ‚Äì Career Skill Building (How to Align Your Academic and Career Goals, Resume Check-up, Getting LinkedIn)Tuesday, November 11 at 5:30PM ESTNewman LibraryHosted by 2 organizations

title: Prof Sam Ben-Yaakov talk about "Intuition¬†in teaching and research of power electronics."
hosted_by: IEEE Power Electronics Society (PELS) Student Branch Chapter at Virginia Tech
description: We‚Äôre excited to host an international level power electronics expert and educator speaker at Virginia Tech for an IEEE PELS Student Branch Chapter and the broad audience. With a wealth of experience in advancing technologies like renewable energy, electric vehicles, and smart grid systems, our speaker will delve into the latest trends and breakthroughs in power electronics. This talk offers students a unique chance to gain insights into the future of the field and explore how power electronics is transforming modern technology and industry. Don‚Äôt miss this opportunity to learn from a leader in power electronics innovation!

title: Soulful Friday
description: Join us Friday, November 14th for Soulful Friday! As the semester picks up, take a well deserved break to relax, recharge, and connect. Expect delicious food, great music, and fun games, everything you need for a good time.

title: NAHM Harvest Festival: Honoring Peoples of Dark Water in Appalachia
description:
Join us in celebrating the end of
Native American Heritage Month
through the
NAHM Harvest Festival: Honoring People of Dark Water in Appalachia
, a community gathering that honors Lumbee traditions and explores the role of food in sustaining cultural identity, health, and community resilience.
Chef Ren√© Locklear White
from the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina will lead a featured presentation expressing cultural and traditional Lumbee foods and traditional foodways tied to the Southeastern Woodlands communities.
The event will also include a
cultural food tasting
,
hands-on workshops
such as a
nixtamalization workshop
, a
tea tasting workshop
, and a
Traditional Eastern Woodland ceramic table
highlighting Indigenous craftsmanship and food traditions. In addition, there will be presentations and displays from
various Virginia Tech departments, programs, and Indigenous community student organizations
, showcasing ongoing efforts to support Indigenous scholarship, sustainability, and community collaboration.
Hosted and coordinated by the
Indigenous Community Garden at Virginia Tech (ICG)
and Ati: Wa:Oki Indigenous Community¬† Center (ICC) and the program is supported by
Indigenous Studies Program,¬†Food Studies Program,
Department of Fish and Wildlife Conservation,
Center for Food Sustainability and Community Transformation,¬†Native@VT,¬†AISES,¬†SACNAS,¬†Solitude-Fraction House, Native and Indigenous Alumni Society,
Biocultural and Ecological Restoration Initiative (BERI
), Virginia Free Farm, the Eastern Woodland Food Work Alliance (TEWFA),
The USDA National Institute of Food and Agriculture and NEXTGEN Program From Learning to Leading: Cultivating the Next Generation of Food and Agriculture Professionals; NEXTGENERATION INCLUSION CONSORTIUM (NIC) FOR BUILDING THE FOOD, AGRICULTURE, NATURAL RESOURCES, AND HUMAN SCIENCES PIPELINE (FANHP).
This event is
free and open-to-the-public
. Attendees are encouraged to register to this event:
https://forms.gle/b6Bj6cY4xvEkvLTv5

title: Experience Africa

The African Graduate Students‚Äô Organization (AGSO) at Virginia Tech is hosting an event titled
EXPERIENCE AFRICA
, November 15, 2025
, at 4
:00 EST
in
Squires Student Center, Meeting Room 305
. Join for an evening of
networking
,
fun,
and
f
ood
and learn how to get involved with AGSO, make friends, and navigate academic life successfully.

title: GEA Graduate Students End-of-Semester Mixer
description:
As part of our mission to build community among all graduate students interested in Engineering and related fields, this event will feature provided food, networking, and plenty of opportunities to connect and unwind before finals.
Come enjoy good company, share your experiences, and make new connections. We‚Äôd love to see you there!
Please register here by November 14:
GEA Mixer RSVP ‚Äì Fill out form

title: Keeping It Real College Life Group
description: Come talk about life with us! This is Church on Main's life group for college students, where all are welcome and loved. We do our best to keep it real, look for grace, and follow God. We meet after the 11:00 service at Church on Main. Currently reading When Christians Get it Wrong by Adam Hamilton.

title: Fall Trivia Night
description: Are you a fall fanatic? Come to the Great Room and compete with a team in Fall Trivia Night! Cozy up with some hot apple cider and donuts for some late-night friendly fun.

title: Studio 72 SNACKSGIVING
description:
It‚Äôs that time of year to give thanks‚Äîand share snacks! Join us for
Studio 72‚Äôs SNACKSGIVING
, a cozy community get-together where everyone brings a favorite snack to share. Whether it‚Äôs sweet, salty, homemade, or store-bought, all snacks are welcome!
Come hang out, snack around, and celebrate creativity, gratitude, and good vibes with your Studio 72 family. Bring something tasty, try something new, and enjoy an evening of laughter and connection.

title: Let's Lock In
description:
DATE: Mondays starting September 15, 2025
TIME: 4:00 ‚Äì 6:00 PM EST
LOCATION: APIDA + Center (140 Squires)
Looking for a weekly boost to stay on track with your classes? Let's Lock In meets once a week ‚Äì every Monday - to give you a dedicated time and space to focus, get support, and make real progress. Join other students in a relaxed, productive environment where tutors are on hand to help with coursework, and other campus resources are just a step away. Think of it like study hall, but better: whether you're tackling tough assignments, prepping for exams, or just trying to stay organized, Let's Lock In is here to help. Drop in, get focused, and leave feeling accomplished.
Co-sponsored with the APIDA + Center/AANAPISI Initiative and the Student Success Center

title: Disrupting Academic Bullying with Bryan Hanson, Grad. School Ombudsperson
hosted_by: Office for Civil Rights Compliance and Prevention Education
description:
Academic bullying remains a persistent and complex issue within higher education, shaped by entrenched hierarchies, hyper-competitive environments, and a culture that often makes toxic behaviors feel untouchable. These dynamics can be especially isolating for graduate students, who frequently navigate unclear boundaries and power imbalances.
One way we hope to frame this discussion is by normalizing the conversation around academic bullying‚Äîrecognizing that part of the problem is how inaccessible or uncomfortable the topic can feel. When we struggle to name these behaviors, we risk allowing them to continue unchecked.
In this event, we will explore the structural and cultural forces that allow academic bullying to persist and consider how graduate students, faculty, and institutions can work together to challenge them. While barriers to change are real, we believe in the power of collective effort to promote healthier, more equitable academic spaces.
Join us to name the problem‚Äîand imagine the solutions.

title: Just Journaling
description:
Just Journaling
November's Theme: Junk Journaling
Tuesday, November 18 | 12:00 - 2:00 PM
Pride Center (Squires 227)
This is a monthly series that explores the mental health benefits of journaling.
Each session will focus a different journaling method¬† to help participants identify which mediums work best to meet their needs. Journals will be provided along with a wide variety of crafting and art supplies, allowing each participant to personalize their experience.
November's session will focus on junk journaling. We'll provide materials for collage, but you are welcome to bring your own as well!
Box lunches will be provided.
All are welcome to join!
For accommodations contact Haleigh Wallace at haleighwallace@vt.edu.

title: International Flamenco Day
description:
Join us for an evening honoring the art, rhythm, and passion of
Flamenco
and to get to know more about each other!
The event will feature a
special talk by our Flamenco teacher, Maria del Carmen Ca√±a Jimenez
, professor of Spanish here at Virginia Tech.
Whether you are a dancer, a music lover, or simply curious about Spanish culture, everyone is welcome!
Ol√© üíÉ!

title: Chinese Program Boba Event
description:
Come relax, sip on bubble tea, and enjoy an afternoon of play! Join us for Bubble Tea and Games, a casual gathering where you can try out a variety of traditional and modern Chinese board and card games. Whether you‚Äôre a seasoned player or completely new, this is a fun way to learn, connect, and share in friendly competition.
We‚Äôll provide the games and teach you the rules‚Äîjust bring your curiosity (and your sweet tooth)!

title: Multilingual Open Mic Night
location: Harper Hall 1025 Community Room, Harper Hall, 240 West Campus Dr, Blacksburg, VA *Enter door into Harper Hall that is facing Cochrane Hall.
description:
Come celebrate at our Intercultural Open Mic Night! Join us for
an evening of spoken word, music, stories, and more, celebrating the unique backgrounds of our community
. Whether you want to perform or just enjoy the show, come share an experience of cultural exchange, community, and connection.
What it is:
An open mic event focused on celebrating diverse cultures through various art forms like poetry, music, storytelling, and more.
What to expect:
A supportive and inclusive atmosphere where everyone can share their culture and identity.
How to participate:
Performers can sign up to share their talents, while the audience can come to listen, learn, and be inspired.
Why it's important:
It's an opportunity to build community, foster intercultural respect, and discover new perspectives through art and performance.
Please sign up using the
link
to perform
https://forms.office.com/r/hkV3xibPXd
Please enter the door into Harper Hall that faces West End/Cochrane Hall.

title: Trivia Contest
description: Last community hour of the semester! The winning suite chooses our Spring field trip.

title: Silent Disco
description: Wesley is hosting a Silent Disco!! This is completely free and open to all!! Bring a friend and your best dance moves!!

title: Mechanical Engineering Graduate Students' Coffee & Donuts Social
description: Get some donuts for them for extra calories and freshly brewed coffee for the extended working hours (courtesy of your PI). Blow off some steam and look forward to some fun chit-chat and lively banter with all the graduate students in the Department of Mechanical Engineering. It is a great platform to discuss work or classes with your ME peers, if you may (we are looking at all you nerds and geeks). Network, socialize, and put on some weight while at it!

title: Henry Dekker Leadership Seminar
description: The Henry Dekker Leadership Seminar will include the speakers Major General Bruce Scott, Major General William Seely, Nancy Brittle, and Dr. Bruce. This event is completely free and will be catered. The dress is business casual.

title: Art of Appreciation
description:
Celebrate community, creativity, and gratitude at Art of Appreciation Night on Wednesday, November 19, 2025, in the Graduate Life Center Auditorium and Info Booth.
This special evening is all about recognizing the people, experiences, and moments that shape our graduate journey. Through interactive activities, creative expression, and meaningful conversations, you‚Äôll have the chance to pause, reflect, and share appreciation in fun and inspiring ways.

title: Saying a Compassionate 'No:' Preserving relationships while setting boundaries
hosted_by: Office for Civil Rights Compliance and Prevention Education
description:
We are often asked to say ‚Äúyes‚Äù to requests that matter
a lot
to our colleagues. Saying ‚Äúno‚Äù to something important can feel risky‚Äîpotentially straining relationships or triggering responses that we‚Äôd rather avoid.¬†Being able to say ‚Äúno‚Äù clearly,¬†compassionately, and with good preparation for the potential response allows us to maintain the boundaries that make sustainable working relationships possible.
In this session, you‚Äôll learn and practice:
A practical framework for saying ‚Äúno‚Äù in ways that protect key relationships and spark constructive dialogue
How to name and stay connected to what truly matters to you as you say ‚Äúno‚Äù
How to respond¬†compassionately and effectively when others are disappointed, upset, or confused by your ‚Äúno.‚Äù
All are welcome to join. Please be sure to RSVP as refreshments will be served.

title: Roots to Wellness: Sit n Sew Workshops
location: Squires 122, Ati: Wa:oki Indigenous Community Center
description:
Roots to Wellness: Sit n Sew Workshops
Take time for yourself while learning sustainable skills to care for your clothing and your well-being. Sit n Sew is a welcoming, creative space where community, self-care, and sustainability meet. All workshops are open to everyone, no prior sewing experience required. Supplies provided‚Äîjust bring your creativity (and a piece of clothing if you‚Äôd like).
Workshops:
Mending Workshop
üóì
Thursday, October 9, 2025 | 5:30‚Äì7:30 PM | Squires 122
Come learn how to mend and alter your own clothing! Bring a beloved item to patch, hem, stitch back up, or add buttons to. Mending is an environmentally conscious practice and a soothing form of self-care. Take time to relax, learn new skills, and care for yourself in community.
Upcycling Workshop
üóì
Thursday, November 20, 2025 | 5:30‚Äì7:30 PM | Squires 122
Give your wardrobe a refresh! Learn how to elevate and transform items you already own through simple alterations, embellishments, and creative changes. Upcycling is a sustainable way to fall in love with your clothes again while practicing mindfulness and care.

title: FRIENDSGIVING: VIETNAMESE SOCIAL DINNER
description: Friendsgiving social dinner held around the Thanksgiving season to bring together students for a night of food, friendship, and cultural exchange. This gathering provides an opportunity for international students, especially Vietnamese students who may not celebrate the holiday with family in the US, to enjoy a warm and inclusive environment. All Vietnamese fellows are welcome to bring their international friends to try our Vietnamese dishes, connect with peers from diverse backgrounds, play traditional Vietnamese board games, and experience our karaoke culture.

hosted_by: Latin American and Iberian Graduate Students Association
description: During these lunches, Latinx graduate students and friends have the opportunity to connect and engage with one another by sharing and celebrating their cultures. These gatherings not only foster social connections but also provide a chance to exchange stories, traditions, and experiences, enriching the community as a whole. Everyone is welcome!

description: Join us for Presentation Night‚Äîan invaluable opportunity to refine your group project before the big day! This supportive and low-pressure environment gives each group the chance to present in front of peers and receive constructive feedback from the professor. You'll get tips on timing, delivery, and content to help strengthen your final presentation. Whether you're looking to boost your confidence, improve clarity, or fine-tune your slides, this is your chance to shine and level up your project. Don‚Äôt miss out on this valuable prep session!

title: AWM Holiday Study Party
description: Join us in the math department Commons Room (MCB 455) for holiday snacks and study buddies on Tuesday, December 2. We know finals week is approaching fast, so we wanted to create a space for you to take a break from studying, enjoy some snacks and visit with friends who are also cramming for finals.

title: Securitas Turner Tuesday - Weekly Community Dinner
description: Every Tuesday this fall, the first five students to meet at Turner Place Dining Hall at 5:15 PM will get their meal covered! Join the Program Director and your fellow Securitas community members for a weekly dinner hangout before your evening class. It‚Äôs a great way to relax, connect, and enjoy good food together. Turner Tuesday runs from August 26 to December 2, 5:15‚Äì6:15 PM. First come, first served!

title: Finding Summer Undergraduate Research Workshop
description:
Interested in a summer internship or undergraduate research experience? Meet with the College of Science and the Office of Undergraduate Research to learn more about paid research and research for credit over the summer!
If you are an individual with a disability and desire an accommodation, please contact Jess Hoopengardner at jessh@vt.edu at least 10 business days prior to the event.

Whether you are a pro at bowling or have never picked up a ball in your life, feel free to join us for an evening of relaxation and community!

description: Learn how to waltz at our Disney-themed social dance! We'll have a one-hour lesson perfect for beginners, followed by two hours of social dancing around the GLC's Multipurpose Room. This is a great opportunity to meet new people and learn to dance, the last of which for this semester. You don't want to miss out!! No partner or experience necessary.

title: CNRE Graduate Student Pizza Social (December)
location: Cheatham Student Lounge on the 1st floorF
hosted_by: Forestry Graduate Student Association at Virginia Tech
description:
The Forest Resources and Environmental Conservation's Graduate Student Association (FGSA) is hosting the last inter-departmental Pizza Social of the semester open to all graduate students in the College of Natural Resources and Environment (CNRE)‚Äîincluding Forest Resources and Environmental Conservation, Fish and Wildlife Conservation, Geography, and Sustainable Biomaterials.
By sharing a meal, we aim to break down barriers to participation while fostering collaboration, interdisciplinary dialogue, and resource sharing among CNRE graduate students. These recurring gatherings will provide a consistent, inclusive space that promotes well-being, builds both professional and personal connections, and strengthens our graduate student community.

title: Books & Bears
description: Come build your very own stuffed critter! You‚Äôll get to stuff it yourself, dress it up, and even design a custom shirt to make it one-of-a-kind. A fun, creative way to make a new fuzzy friend!

title: Reading Day with QGPA
description: On reading day, December 11, students will be invited to spend time together in queer community. Whether individuals are looking for time to work and study, or to socialize, we are providing a space to prepare for the end of the semester together. We will provide food, drinks, and de-stress items such as fidget toys for individuals who attend.

title: Finals Frenzy - Finals Survival Kits
description: Stop by Squires Room 226 on the 2nd floor of Squires to put together your Finals Survival Kit! We will be there from 2-4, or until supplies runs out!

hosted_by: Institute for Operations Research and the Management Science Student Chapter
description:
The INFORMS Student Chapter at Virginia Tech will host
Dr. Shu-Kai Fan
from the National Taipei University of Technology for a seminar titled
‚ÄúOptimizing floating crane operations for efficient bulk product transshipments on inland waterways.‚Äù
The event will be held virtually via Microsoft Teams; in-person viewing in Durham 260.
The event is open to all students and anyone¬†interested in the fields of Operations Research, Manufacturing Systems and Processes, and Management Sciences
. It's a great opportunity to engage with cutting-edge research and interact with a leading scholar in the field!

title: New Fellow Welcome Event
hosted_by: Interfaces of Global Change Graduate Student Organization
description: We are hosting a dinner mixer for IGC fellows, so fellows joining in January 2026 can get to know current their new cohort and current fellows who have been with the IGC for longer. We will provide dinner and snacks, as well as arts and crafts, so students can bond over a shared activity and food.

title: Gobblernights: The Boardwalk
description: Step right up for Gobblernights: The Boardwalk! We're bringing all the summer vibes to the middle of winter! Join us on Friday, January 23rd from 8‚Äì10:30 PM in Squires Student Center¬†for a night of boardwalk fun, games, and prizes. Enjoy classic summer activities, play to earn tickets, and trade them in for the chance to win exciting prizes. It‚Äôs the perfect way to beat the winter chill and make your own sunshine with friends. Don‚Äôt miss out on this warm-weather escape right here on campus!

hosted_by: Computer Science Graduate Council at Virginia Tech
description: CSGC officers meet every other week in this meeting to review updates from the CS department and plan how to effectively communicate these updates to the general CS graduate student body. We also make necessary arrangements for any upcoming events being organized by CSGC. While this is an internal CSGC meeting, the general CS graduate student population is welcome to attend the meeting as well.

title: Black Excellence in Uniform: Celebrating Service and Legacy
description:
In honor of the 100th anniversary of Black History Month, the BCO presents
Black Excellence in Uniform: Celebrating Service and Legacy
‚Äîa powerful¬† panel dedicated to educating, inspiring, and honoring the service of African American military members, both past and present. This event aims to foster meaningful dialogue between Virginia Tech cadets, students, and distinguished panelists who serve or have served in active duty or reserve roles. By showcasing the resilience, leadership, and contributions of Black service members, we seek to highlight their enduring legacy and motivate the next generation to lead with purpose, pride, and excellence.
